description.narrative: Three decades of conflict, natural disasters and deteriorating economic conditions have caused massive population movements, both within Afghanistan and towards neighboring countries. Since the fall of Taliban regime, the massive inflow of more than 5 million refugees has increased the overall population of Afghanistan by 20 percent, with some regions having been affected more severely than others. Over the past three years, the worsening of security conditions in the South, East and Western provinces have forced further waves of population movements and internal displacement. Unable to reintegrate in the communities of origin due to the lack of social and economic opportunities and security, many of the population, particularly returnees and IDPs have sought for better life through secondary migration toward major urban centers within Afghanistan. Herat, Mazar-e-Sharif and Bamiyan are some of key cities where significant number of migrated population, refugees and IDP are currently living in displacement. It is estimated that 148,000 persons returned to Herat, 100,000 to Mazar-e-Sharif and 25,000 to Bamiyan. There are 1.9 million registered refugees in Pakistan and one million in Iran, and estimated two million illegal migrants in Pakistan and 1.4 million in Iran. Their imminent deportation will add to the strain currently experienced. Approximately 530 persons per day are reported to have been deported from Iran during the past eight months and the trend is likely to continue. Half of them are settling in Herat and others in Farah and Nimroz. Reportedly, Iran will issue about 50,000 exit permits per month till August 2012. In addition, ongoing drought in northern, northeastern and western Afghanistan is likely to place 1.5-2 million people into difficult living conditions, which will undoubtedly force them to move to urban centres, Mazar-e-Sharif being one.The arrival of these additional people into Herat, Mazar-e-Sharif and Bamiyan cities will rapidly exert pressure on local infrastructure and services exacerbating pre-existing vulnerability conditions. This will impact on the way urban development is managed particularly in settlement planning and providing access to basic services, infrastructure and labor markets. Status quo is not an option and would further lead to instability of settlements and the cities themselves.Moreover, the Government of Afghanistan and the international community have pledged their continued support to improve human security, governance and development in the transition cities. If local people participate in planning processes and see little or no result from external development assistance they may become disillusioned and frustrated with their governance. Many people may be forced for their own survival to engage in illicit activities such as drugs or can be attracted to re-join the insurgents to obtain incomes.The situation thus is dire and has to be addressed now. Based on its global mandate on urban development and proven track record in Afghanistan over the past 20 years, UN-HABITAT is uniquely placed to support communities in these cities and enable them to live a dignified life. Promotion of community solidarity through empowerment, job opportunities, easier access to infrastructure, and strengthened and accountable local governance are urgently required in order to prevent instability of the cities.One of the key lessons learnt by UN-HABITAT in Afghanistan is that anti-governmental elements (AGEs) do not infiltrate where communities are organized and empowered. As the AGEs will become more active when the winter ends early next year, it is important to launch this proposed project right away.
